awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Defects and Polarons in Complex Materials
awd_abstract_narration:
NONTECHNICAL SUMMARY

This CAREER award supports research and education on the computational modelling of defects in complex materials that are used for energy, electronics, and optoelectronics applications. 

Defects play a crucial role in altering the properties of many materials, some of which are of high technological relevance and central to our daily life. For example, the electrical conductivity of semiconductors such as silicon and gallium arsenide can be drastically modified by adding minute concentrations of impurities, enabling a variety of microelectronic devices (such as the ubiquitous transistor) that are present in the microchips inside our current computers, smart phones, and tablets. On the other hand, defects can be detrimental to device performance, as is the case for defects that limit the efficiency of solar cells. Our ability to control the type and amount of defects present determines if a given material will be suitable for device applications. Understanding and controlling defects is therefore crucial to the development of novel materials for electronics and optoelectronics. Using advanced methods of electronic structure theory and supercomputers, the PI will investigate the role of defects in a series of complex materials that exhibit an array of exciting physical properties. The research may enhance the existing properties, and could lead to the discovery of new ones that can be used in novel device designs.

In addition, this project will have significant educational value, incorporating training of graduate and K-12 high-school students. The graduate students will learn cutting-edge computational methods and advanced concepts in materials theory; they will also participate in an outreach program that involves teaching scientific programing to high-school students, enticing them to a career in science and technology. Through summer internships, high-school students will work on developing data-manipulation tools that will help the graduate students with complex data visualization. The tools will be freely available through the PI's research website.


TECHNICAL SUMMARY

This CAREER award supports research and education on the computational modelling of defects and charge localization in complex materials that are used for energy, electronics, and optoelectronics applications. 

The properties of most materials are strongly affected by the presence of defects. For example, adding minute concentrations of impurities to a semiconductor can drastically change its electrical conductivity by several orders of magnitude, transforming a good insulator into an excellent conductor. Defects can also be detrimental to device performance, as in the case of solar cells, where defects cause unwanted nonradiative carrier recombination, and strongly impact efficiency. Computer modelling based on density functional theory has turned into a powerful tool in the study of defects in various types of materials, providing information on concentrations, and on electrical and optical activities. These calculations often complement experiments by giving access to important properties and phenomena that are difficult to probe at the atomic scale. 

In this project the PI will use state-of-the-art computational methods to investigate the role of defects in oxides made of elements with partially filled d or f shells. The materials of interest include perovskites, layered perovskites, and pyrochlores. These materials have potential to enable novel devices and functionalities, as their most interesting properties are strongly influenced by the presence of impurities and defects. This project will advance fundamental understanding of the impact of defects and impurities on the electronic and optical properties of these complex materials. In a crucial step towards enabling device applications, the project will provide information on equilibrium defect concentrations, electrical and optical activities, and the relation between defects and charge carriers and migration. Ultimately, it will serve to identify defects that are detrimental to materials performance in devices, and will provide a basis to engineer defects, through doping or alloying, to enhance or broaden materials functionality.

In addition, this project will have significant educational value, incorporating training of graduate and K-12 high-school students. The graduate students will learn cutting-edge computational methods and advanced concepts in materials theory; they will also participate in an outreach program that involves teaching scientific programing to high-school students, enticing them to a career in science and technology. Through summer internships, high-school students will work on developing data-manipulation tools that will help the graduate students with complex data visualization. The tools will be freely available through the PI's research website.

por.por_cntn:
The objectives of this CAREER AWARD were to support research and education efforts focused on computational modeling of defects and charge-carrier localization in complex materials. Defects play a critical role in determining the properties of most materials. Even minute impurities added to a semiconductor can dramatically change its electrical conductivity, turning it from an insulator to a conductor. Defects can also negatively impact device performance, such as in solar cells, where they cause undesired carrier recombination, reducing efficiency. Identifying defects is challenging for experimentalists, often requiring a combination of techniques and expertise.

Computational modeling based on density functional theory (DFT) has emerged as a powerful tool for studying defects in various materials. It provides valuable information on defect concentrations, electrical and optical behaviors, complementing experimental findings by revealing atomic-scale properties and phenomena that are difficult to observe directly.

This project aims to achieve several major goals. First, it seeks to investigate the role of defects in materials novel complex materials using advanced computational methods that surpass standard approximations in DFT. Second, it aims to train graduate students in cutting-edge computational techniques and advanced concepts in materials physics. Third, the research outcomes will be integrated into educational settings, benefiting classroom students. Fourth, the project aims to instill the values of higher education and scientific research in K-12 high school students through summer internships in the research group led by the principal investigator (PI).

The materials of interest encompass various crystal structures and properties, including wide-band-gap semiconductors, Mott insulators, ionic conductors, high-k dielectrics, ferroelectrics, ferromagnets, and multiferroics. These materials exhibit unique characteristics due to their narrow bands and strong electron-phonon coupling, making them prone to charge localization in the form of small polarons. Impurities and defects have a significant influence on the properties of these materials. Therefore, this project advances our fundamental understanding of the impact of defects and impurities on the electronic and optical properties of complex materials. This knowledge is crucial for utilizing these materials in various devices, as it provides insights into equilibrium defect concentrations, electrical and optical behaviors, the relationship between defects and charge carriers, and migration. Ultimately, it enables the identification of detrimental defects and lays the groundwork for engineering defects through doping or alloying to enhance or broaden the functionality of materials.

In addition to its scientific contributions, this research had a significant educational value. It involved training graduate students and engaging K-12 students and undergraduate students, integrating research outcomes into educational environments. Graduate students acquired expertise in state-of-the-art computational methods and advanced concepts in materials theory. They participated in an outreach program focused on teaching scientific programming to high school and undergraduate students, inspiring them to pursue careers in science and technology. High school and undergraduate students had the opportunity to contribute to the research group by developing data manipulation tools through summer internships at the University of Delaware. Emphasizing inclusivity, the project aimed to broaden the participation of underrepresented groups in scientific research. Beyond its educational value, the proposed research significantly contributed to the foundation for developing complex materials for various energy applications.

This award resulted in 35 publications in peer-review journals with over 700 citations (according to Google Scholar), including 2 in Physical Review Letters, 1 in Advanced Materials, 1 in Langmuir, 1 in Journal of Physical Chemistry Letters, and 1 in Materials Today Communications. 

This award directly supported two graduate students; both are members of underrepresented groups in STEM.  One student is now a staff member at First Solar Inc., and the other is a postdoctoral researcher at the Los Alamos National Laboratory. 

This award indirectly supported three visiting postdoctoral researchers: the first (05/2017-06/2018) was a professor from the Universidade Federal Fluminense, Brazil, the second (03/2016-12/2016) was a postdoctoral researcher in China, and now an Associated Professor at North China Electric Power University, China, and the third was a postdoctoral researcher at the Universidade Estadual Paulista, Brazil, (10/2021-02/2022) and (10/01/2022-10/31/2022).  It also supported two graduate students from abroad, both members from underrepresented groups in STEM.  The first, a Master student from Thailand (07/2018-01/2019), and now a Ph.D. student in the PI’s group, and the other (09/2020-08/2021) from Beijing Computational Science Research Center, China.

As part of the outreach activities, three K-12 students spent the Summer in the PI’s lab to learn programming and help with some Python postprocessing codes.  One in the summer of 2017, the other in the summer of 2018, and the third in the summer of 2019. Three undergraduate students also participated in the summer activities. One from Shippensburg University, PA, (07/2017-08/2017), the second from Georgia Tech, GA, (06/2017-08/2017 and 06/2018-08/2018), and the third from the University of Florida (06/2022-08/2022).  Due to the Covid-19 pandemic, it was not possible to host K-12 students in the summers of 2020-2022.  From this group, two were members of underrepresented groups in STEM.
